name: Pythagorean trigonometric identity
explanation: The fundamental identity stating that the square of cosine of an angle plus the square of sine of the same angle equals one.

name: Sine rule for triangle side ratios
explanation: A formula relating the ratios of sides of a triangle to the sines of their opposite angles, used to solve triangles.

name: Cosine rule for triangle side lengths
explanation: A formula expressing the length of one side of a triangle in terms of the other two sides and the cosine of the included angle.

name: Cosine of difference formula
explanation: An identity expressing cosine of the difference of two angles as the product of cosines plus the product of sines.

name: Cosine of sum formula
explanation: An identity expressing cosine of the sum of two angles as the product of cosines minus the product of sines.

name: Double angle formula for cosine (cos 2A)
explanation: An identity expressing cosine of twice an angle in terms of squares of cosine and sine of the original angle.

name: Sine of sum formula
explanation: An identity expressing sine of the sum of two angles as the sum of products of sine and cosine of the individual angles.

name: Sine of difference formula
explanation: An identity expressing sine of the difference of two angles as the difference of products of sine and cosine of the individual angles.

name: Tangent of sum formula
explanation: An identity expressing tangent of the sum of two angles as a ratio involving tangents of the individual angles.

name: Tangent of difference formula
explanation: An identity expressing tangent of the difference of two angles as a ratio involving tangents of the individual angles.

name: Double angle formula for sine (sin 2A)
explanation: An identity expressing sine of twice an angle as twice the product of sine and cosine of the original angle.

name: Alternate double angle formula for sine
explanation: Another form of the double angle formula for sine, expressing sin 2A in terms of sine or cosine squared.

name: Alternate double angle formula for cosine
explanation: Forms of the double angle formula for cosine expressed using sine squared or cosine squared.

name: Double angle formula for tangent (tan 2A)
explanation: An identity expressing tangent of twice an angle as a ratio involving tangent squared of the original angle.

name: Power-reduction formula for cosine squared
explanation: An identity expressing cosine squared of an angle as half the sum of one and cosine of twice the angle.

name: Power-reduction formula for sine squared
explanation: An identity expressing sine squared of an angle as half the difference of one and cosine of twice the angle.

name: Product-to-sum formula: 2 cos A cos B
explanation: An identity expressing twice the product of cosines of two angles as the sum of cosines of their sum and difference.

name: Product-to-sum formula: 2 sin A cos B
explanation: An identity expressing twice the product of sine and cosine of two angles as the sum of sines of their sum and difference.

name: Product-to-sum formula: 2 sin A sin B
explanation: An identity expressing twice the product of sines of two angles as the difference of cosines of their difference and sum.

name: Product-to-sum formula: 2 cos A sin B
explanation: An identity expressing twice the product of cosine and sine of two angles as the difference of sines of their sum and difference.

name: Sum-to-product formula for cosine sum
explanation: An identity expressing the sum of cosines of two angles as twice the product of cosines of half their sum and half their difference.

name: Sum-to-product formula for cosine difference
explanation: An identity expressing the difference of cosines of two angles as negative twice the product of sines of half their sum and half their difference.

name: Sum-to-product formula for sine sum
explanation: An identity expressing the sum of sines of two angles as twice the product of sine of half their sum and cosine of half their difference.

name: Sum-to-product formula for sine difference
explanation: An identity expressing the difference of sines of two angles as twice the product of cosine of half their sum and sine of half their difference.

name: circle drawing with given radius
explanation: Constructing a circle using a compass with a specified radius from a given center point.

name: use of straight edge in geometric constructions
explanation: Using a straight edge tool to draw precise straight lines in geometric diagrams.

name: use of compass in geometric constructions
explanation: Employing a compass to draw arcs and circles accurately in geometric constructions.

name: use of ruler in geometric constructions
explanation: Applying a ruler to measure lengths and draw straight lines with precision in geometric diagrams.

name: use of protractor in geometric constructions
explanation: Using a protractor to measure and construct angles accurately in geometric diagrams.

name: use of set square in geometric constructions
explanation: Employing a set square to draw perpendicular and parallel lines and specific angle measures in constructions.

name: coordinate plane plotting
explanation: Locating and plotting points on the Cartesian coordinate plane using ordered pairs (x, y).

name: linear relationship representation in tables
explanation: Representing linear relationships between variables using numerical tables showing input-output pairs.

name: linear relationship representation in graphs
explanation: Plotting linear relationships on coordinate axes to visualize the relationship between variables.

name: slope as rate of change
explanation: Understanding the slope of a line as the rate at which the dependent variable changes with respect to the independent variable.

name: interpretation of start value in linear functions
explanation: Recognizing the y-intercept as the initial value or starting point of a linear relationship in real-life contexts.

name: point of intersection of two linear graphs
explanation: Identifying the coordinate point where two linear graphs meet, representing the solution to simultaneous equations.

name: strategies for solving two linear relationships
explanation: Using graphical, numerical, or mental methods to find solutions to problems involving two linear equations.

name: application of Pythagoras theorem in right-angled triangles
explanation: Using the Pythagorean theorem to find missing side lengths in right-angled triangles, especially in height and distance problems.

name: use of trigonometric ratios in right-angled triangles
explanation: Applying sine, cosine, and tangent ratios to find unknown sides or angles in right-angled triangles.

name: identification of axes of symmetry in shapes
explanation: Locating lines that divide shapes into mirror-image halves, demonstrating symmetry.

name: recognition of images under translation
explanation: Understanding how points and shapes move uniformly in a given direction without rotation or reflection.

name: recognition of images under central symmetry
explanation: Identifying points and shapes reflected through a central point producing congruent images.

name: recognition of images under axial symmetry
explanation: Identifying points and shapes reflected across a line (axis) producing mirror images.

name: recognition of images under rotation
explanation: Understanding how points and shapes turn about a fixed point through a specified angle and direction.

name: investigation of enlargements with scale factor k
explanation: Studying how shapes change size by a scale factor k, where k is a positive rational number, affecting dimensions and area.

name: centre of enlargement in enlargements
explanation: The fixed point from which all points of a shape are expanded or contracted during an enlargement.

name: proof by contradiction
explanation: A deductive reasoning method where the negation of a statement is assumed and shown to lead to a contradiction, thereby proving the original statement true.

name: use of theorem, proof, axiom, corollary, converse, implies in geometry
explanation: Understanding and applying fundamental logical terms and structures used in geometric reasoning and proofs.

name: proof of theorems concerning ratios in geometry
explanation: Demonstrating geometric theorems that involve proportional relationships between segments or areas.

name: use of slope to determine parallelism of lines
explanation: Showing that two lines are parallel if and only if their slopes are equal.

name: use of slope to determine perpendicularity of lines
explanation: Showing that two lines are perpendicular if the product of their slopes is -1.

name: recognition of linear equation in standard form ax + by + c = 0
explanation: Identifying and understanding the general form of a linear equation representing a straight line in the plane.

name: calculation of area of triangle using coordinates
explanation: Finding the area of a triangle given the coordinates of its vertices using coordinate geometry formulas.

name: equation of circle in center-radius form (x-h)^2 + (y-k)^2 = r^2
explanation: Representing a circle with center (h,k) and radius r as the set of points satisfying this equation.

name: equation of circle in general form x^2 + y^2 + 2gx + 2fy + c = 0
explanation: Expressing a circle in expanded form where the center and radius can be derived from coefficients g, f, and c.

name: perpendicular distance from a point to a line
explanation: Calculating the shortest distance between a given point and a specified line in the coordinate plane.
broader_concept: Distance and measurement in coordinate geometry

name: angle between two lines
explanation: Determining the measure of the angle formed where two lines intersect using their slopes.

name: internal division of a line segment in ratio m:n
explanation: Finding a point on a line segment that divides it internally into parts proportional to m and n.
broader_concept: Ratio and proportion in coordinate geometry

name: use of Pythagoras theorem in 2D problem solving
explanation: Applying the Pythagorean theorem specifically to two-dimensional geometric problems to find missing lengths.

name: calculation of triangle area using trigonometry
explanation: Finding the area of a triangle using formulas involving sine of an included angle and side lengths.

name: application of sine rule in triangle problem solving
explanation: Using the sine rule to find unknown sides or angles in any triangle based on ratios of sides to sines of opposite angles.

name: application of cosine rule in triangle problem solving
explanation: Using the cosine rule to find unknown sides or angles in any triangle based on side lengths and included angle cosine.

name: definition of sine and cosine functions for all angle values
explanation: Extending the definitions of sine and cosine to all real values of angles, including beyond acute angles, typically using the unit circle.

name: definition of tangent function
explanation: Defining the tangent of an angle as the ratio of sine to cosine or as the slope of the line forming the angle with the x-axis.

name: area of sector of a circle
explanation: Calculating the area of a sector (a 'slice') of a circle based on the radius and the central angle in radians or degrees.

name: length of arc of a circle
explanation: Finding the length of an arc of a circle using the radius and the measure of the central angle in radians or degrees.

name: trigonometric ratios in surd form
explanation: Expressing sine, cosine, and tangent values in exact surd (irrational root) form rather than decimal approximations.

name: application of trigonometry in 3D problem solving
explanation: Using trigonometric concepts and ratios to solve problems involving three-dimensional figures and spatial reasoning.

name: graphing sine function
explanation: Plotting the sine function over an interval to understand its periodic nature, amplitude, and zeros.

name: graphing cosine function
explanation: Plotting the cosine function over an interval to understand its periodic nature, amplitude, and zeros.

name: graphing tangent function
explanation: Plotting the tangent function over an interval, noting its periodicity, asymptotes, and zeros.

name: graphing trigonometric functions of form f(θ) = a + b sin(cθ)
explanation: Plotting sine functions with vertical shifts, amplitude changes, and frequency changes determined by parameters a, b, and c.

name: graphing trigonometric functions of form g(θ) = a + b cos(cθ)
explanation: Plotting cosine functions with vertical shifts, amplitude changes, and frequency changes determined by parameters a, b, and c.

name: solving trigonometric equations Sin nθ = 0
explanation: Finding all angle solutions θ where the sine of n times θ equals zero, including general solutions.

name: solving trigonometric equations Cos nθ = 1/2
explanation: Finding all angle solutions θ where the cosine of n times θ equals one half, including general solutions.

name: use of radian measure of angles
explanation: Measuring angles in radians, where one radian is the angle subtended by an arc equal in length to the radius of the circle.

name: derivation of fundamental trigonometric formulae
explanation: Proving key trigonometric identities and formulas that relate sine, cosine, tangent, and their combinations.

name: application of trigonometric formulae 1-24
explanation: Using a comprehensive set of trigonometric identities and formulas to solve various problems.

name: 2.1 Synthetic geometry
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: 2.1 Synthetic geometry

name: natural numbers (N)
explanation: The set of positive integers starting from 1, used for counting and ordering.

name: integers (Z)
explanation: The set of whole numbers including positive, negative numbers and zero.

name: rational numbers (Q)
explanation: Numbers that can be expressed as the quotient of two integers, including fractions and decimals that are terminating or repeating.

name: irrational numbers
explanation: Numbers that cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers and have non-terminating, non-repeating decimal expansions.

name: real numbers (R)
explanation: The set of all rational and irrational numbers combined, representing all points on the number line.

name: complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Numbers expressed as a + ib, where a and b are real numbers and i is the imaginary unit with i² = -1.

name: Argand diagram representation of complex numbers
explanation: A graphical representation of complex numbers on a plane with the real axis as x-axis and the imaginary axis as y-axis.

name: modulus of a complex number
explanation: The distance of a complex number from the origin on the Argand diagram, calculated as the square root of the sum of squares of its real and imaginary parts.

name: complex conjugate
explanation: The complex number obtained by changing the sign of the imaginary part of a complex number a + ib to a - ib.

name: finite decimal representation
explanation: Decimal numbers that have a limited number of digits after the decimal point.

name: repeating decimal representation
explanation: Decimal numbers where a sequence of digits repeats infinitely.

name: equivalence of fractions, decimals, and percentages
explanation: Understanding that fractions, decimals, and percentages can represent the same quantity in different forms.

name: addition of natural numbers using decomposition
explanation: Breaking numbers into parts to simplify addition within natural numbers.

name: multiplication of natural numbers using arrays
explanation: Using rectangular arrays to model and understand multiplication as repeated addition.

name: skip counting for multiplication
explanation: Counting forward by a number other than one to understand multiplication.

name: inverse operations within natural numbers
explanation: Understanding subtraction as the inverse of addition and division as the inverse of multiplication within natural numbers.

name: commutative property of addition and multiplication
explanation: The property that changing the order of addends or factors does not change the sum or product.

name: associative property of addition and multiplication
explanation: The property that changing the grouping of addends or factors does not change the sum or product.

name: distributive property of multiplication over addition
explanation: The property that multiplying a sum by a number is the same as multiplying each addend by the number and then adding the products.

name: order of operations including brackets
explanation: Rules that define the sequence in which operations should be performed in an expression to obtain the correct result.

name: addition with negative numbers
explanation: Performing addition operations where one or both numbers are negative, following arithmetic rules for signs.

name: subtraction with negative numbers
explanation: Performing subtraction operations involving negative numbers, applying rules for sign changes.

name: multiplication with negative numbers
explanation: Multiplying numbers where one or both factors are negative, following sign rules.

name: division with negative numbers
explanation: Dividing numbers where one or both numbers are negative, applying sign rules.

name: number line representation of integers
explanation: Using a number line to visually represent integers and their order.

name: number line representation of rational numbers
explanation: Using a number line to represent rational numbers including fractions and decimals.

name: number line representation of real numbers
explanation: Using a number line to represent all real numbers including irrational numbers.

name: geometric construction of square roots
explanation: Using geometric methods to construct lengths representing square roots such as √2 and √3.

name: proof of irrationality of √2
explanation: A mathematical proof demonstrating that √2 cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers.

name: prime factorization
explanation: Expressing a number as a product of its prime factors.

name: expressing numbers in scientific notation
explanation: Writing numbers in the form a × 10^n where 1 ≤ a < 10 and n is an integer.

name: arithmetic sequences
explanation: Sequences of numbers where the difference between consecutive terms is constant.

name: geometric sequences
explanation: Sequences where each term is found by multiplying the previous term by a constant ratio.

name: sum of arithmetic series
explanation: The total obtained by adding the terms of an arithmetic sequence up to n terms.

name: sum of finite geometric series
explanation: The sum of the first n terms of a geometric sequence.

name: sum to infinity of geometric series
explanation: The limit of the sum of terms of a geometric series as the number of terms approaches infinity, when the common ratio's absolute value is less than 1.

name: proof by mathematical induction
explanation: A method of proving statements for all natural numbers by proving a base case and an inductive step.

name: factorisation using induction
explanation: Proving factorisation properties of expressions using induction, such as divisibility results.

name: limits of sequences
explanation: The value that the terms of a sequence approach as the index goes to infinity.

name: recurring decimals as infinite geometric series
explanation: Interpreting repeating decimals as sums of infinite geometric series to express them as fractions.

name: percentage calculation
explanation: Finding a part of a whole expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: comparison of proportions using fractions, decimals, and percentages
explanation: Using equivalent forms to compare relative sizes of quantities.

name: rounding to specified degree of accuracy
explanation: Approximating numbers by reducing digits to a given precision.

name: estimation and approximation of calculations
explanation: Making rough calculations to find approximate values and justify their reasonableness.

name: expressing non-zero positive rational numbers in scientific notation
explanation: Writing positive rational numbers as a × 10^n with 1 ≤ a < 10 and integer n.

name: square numbers
explanation: Numbers obtained by multiplying an integer by itself.

name: cube numbers
explanation: Numbers obtained by raising an integer to the power of three.

name: square roots
explanation: The number which when squared gives the original number.

name: reciprocals
explanation: The multiplicative inverse of a number, which when multiplied by the original number gives 1.

name: rules of indices for multiplication
explanation: The rule that a^p × a^q = a^(p+q) for the same base a.

name: rules of indices for division
explanation: The rule that a^p ÷ a^q = a^(p−q) for the same base a.

name: zero exponent rule
explanation: Any non-zero number raised to the power zero equals one, a^0 = 1.

name: power of a power rule
explanation: The rule that (a^p)^q = a^(pq).

name: negative exponent rule
explanation: The rule that a^(−p) = 1 / a^p for a ≠ 0.

name: power of a product rule
explanation: The rule that (ab)^p = a^p × b^p.

name: power of a quotient rule
explanation: The rule that (a/b)^p = a^p / b^p.

name: logarithm product rule
explanation: The logarithm of a product is the sum of the logarithms: log_a(xy) = log_a x + log_a y.

name: logarithm quotient rule
explanation: The logarithm of a quotient is the difference of the logarithms: log_a(x/y) = log_a x − log_a y.

name: logarithm power rule
explanation: The logarithm of a power is the exponent times the logarithm: log_a(x^q) = q log_a x.

name: logarithm of base and one
explanation: log_a a = 1 and log_a 1 = 0 for any valid base a.

name: change of base formula for logarithms
explanation: The formula log_a x = (log_b x) / (log_b a) allowing calculation of logarithms with any base.

name: profit and loss percentage calculations
explanation: Calculating profit or loss as a percentage of cost price or selling price.

name: compound interest calculation (up to 3 years)
explanation: Calculating interest on principal and accumulated interest over a period not exceeding three years.

name: income tax calculation at standard rate
explanation: Calculating income tax applying a fixed standard rate to taxable income.

name: net pay calculation including deductions
explanation: Determining take-home pay after subtracting specified deductions from gross income.

name: average speed calculation
explanation: Calculating speed by dividing total distance traveled by total time taken.

name: perimeter calculation of plane figures
explanation: Finding the total length around 2D shapes such as triangles, rectangles, squares, and discs.

name: area calculation of plane figures
explanation: Calculating the surface enclosed within 2D shapes including triangles, rectangles, squares, parallelograms, trapeziums, and sectors of discs.

name: surface area calculation of solids
explanation: Calculating the total area of all faces or surfaces of 3D solids such as rectangular solids, cylinders, cones, spheres, and hemispheres.

name: volume calculation of solids
explanation: Determining the amount of space occupied by 3D solids including rectangular solids, cylinders, cones, spheres, and hemispheres.

name: nets of 3D solids
explanation: Two-dimensional patterns that can be folded to form 3D solids such as prisms, cylinders, cones, and rectangular solids.

name: relationship between circumference and diameter of a circle
explanation: Understanding that the circumference of a circle is proportional to its diameter, with the constant of proportionality π.

name: trapezoidal rule for area approximation
explanation: A numerical method to estimate the area under a curve by dividing it into trapezoids and summing their areas.

name: order of magnitude estimation
explanation: Assessing the scale or size of a quantity by rounding to the nearest power of ten.

name: percentage error calculation
explanation: Calculating the difference between an approximate value and an exact value expressed as a percentage of the exact value.

name: tolerance in measurements
explanation: The allowable deviation from a specified value in measurement or calculation.

name: accumulated error by addition or subtraction
explanation: The total error resulting from successive addition or subtraction operations.

name: unit conversion between metric and imperial systems
explanation: Changing measurements from one system of units to another using conversion factors.

name: present value calculation for loan repayments and investments
explanation: Determining the current worth of a future sum of money or stream of cash flows given a specified rate of return.

name: polynomial expression classification by degree
explanation: Classification of polynomial expressions based on the highest power of the variable, such as linear (degree 1), quadratic (degree 2), and cubic (degree 3) polynomials.

name: binomial and trinomial polynomial expressions
explanation: Identification of polynomial expressions containing exactly two terms (binomial) or three terms (trinomial).

name: coefficient identification in polynomial expressions
explanation: Determining the numerical factor multiplying each power of the variable in a polynomial expression.

name: addition and subtraction of polynomial expressions
explanation: Combining polynomial expressions by adding or subtracting like terms to simplify the expression.

name: multiplying polynomial expressions (expanding)
explanation: Using the distributive law to multiply polynomial expressions and then simplifying the result.

name: perfect square polynomial expansion
explanation: Expanding polynomials of the form (x ± a)^2 into x^2 ± 2ax + a^2.

name: difference of two squares expansion
explanation: Expanding expressions of the form (x - a)(x + a) into x^2 - a^2.

name: dividing algebraic expressions by monomial
explanation: Simplifying algebraic fractions where the denominator is a monomial factor common to each term of the numerator.

name: dividing algebraic expressions by polynomial factor
explanation: Simplifying algebraic fractions where the denominator is a polynomial factor of the numerator, including use of long division.

name: long division of polynomials
explanation: A method to divide one polynomial by another, producing a quotient and remainder.

name: polynomial functions and evaluation
explanation: Functions defined by polynomials where the value is found by substituting the independent variable and simplifying.

name: forming expressions for geometric dimensions using polynomials
explanation: Expressing geometric quantities like area, volume, and perimeter as polynomial functions of variables representing dimensions.

name: factorising algebraic expressions by highest common factor
explanation: Extracting the greatest common monomial factor from each term of an algebraic expression.

name: factorising by grouping
explanation: Rearranging terms and factoring common factors from pairs of terms to factorise expressions.

name: factorising difference of two squares
explanation: Expressing a^2 - b^2 as (a - b)(a + b).

name: factorising quadratic expressions by trial and error
explanation: Finding factors of quadratic expressions by identifying pairs of numbers that satisfy sum and product conditions.

name: factorising quadratic expressions using quadratic formula
explanation: Using roots found from the quadratic formula to express a quadratic as a product of linear factors.

name: factorising sum and difference of two cubes
explanation: Expressing x^3 ± y^3 as (x ± y)(x^2 ∓ xy + y^2).

name: simplifying algebraic fractions by common denominator
explanation: Adding or subtracting algebraic fractions by finding a common denominator and combining numerators.

name: multiplying and dividing algebraic fractions
explanation: Multiplying numerators and denominators separately for multiplication; inverting and multiplying for division.

name: binomial expansion using Pascal's triangle and combinations
explanation: Expanding (a + b)^n using binomial coefficients from Pascal's triangle or combinations formula.

name: algebraic identities and equating coefficients
explanation: Using identities true for all variable values to equate coefficients of like powers and solve for unknowns.

name: partial fraction decomposition using algebraic identities
explanation: Expressing rational functions as sums of simpler fractions by equating numerators and solving for constants.

name: manipulating formulae to make a variable the subject
explanation: Rearranging equations to express one variable explicitly in terms of others.

name: solving simultaneous linear equations by substitution and elimination
explanation: Finding values of variables satisfying two linear equations using substitution or elimination methods.

name: solving simultaneous linear equations with three variables
explanation: Reducing three equations with three unknowns to two equations with two unknowns, then solving stepwise.

name: solving simultaneous equations in context
explanation: Formulating and solving simultaneous equations derived from real-world problems.

name: radian measure and arc length formula
explanation: Measuring angles in radians where 1 radian subtends an arc equal to the radius; arc length l = rθ.

name: area of sector formula
explanation: Area of a sector of a circle is (1/2) r^2 θ, where θ is in radians.

name: basic trigonometric ratios
explanation: Definitions of sine, cosine, and tangent as ratios of sides in a right-angled triangle.

name: calculator use for trigonometric functions and inverse functions
explanation: Using calculator keys to find sine, cosine, tangent values and their inverses for given angles or ratios.

name: special angles trigonometric values
explanation: Exact sine, cosine, and tangent values for 30°, 45°, and 60° angles expressed as fractions or surds.

name: unit circle coordinates as cosine and sine
explanation: Any point on the unit circle has coordinates (cos θ, sin θ), defining trigonometric functions.

name: signs of trigonometric functions in quadrants
explanation: Determining positivity or negativity of sine, cosine, and tangent in each of the four quadrants.

name: sine rule for any triangle
explanation: Relates sides and sines of opposite angles: a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C.

name: area of triangle using sine
explanation: Area = (1/2) ab sin C, where a and b are sides enclosing angle C.

name: ambiguous case in sine rule
explanation: Situations where two different triangles satisfy given two sides and a non-included angle.

name: cosine rule for any triangle
explanation: Relates one side to the other two sides and included angle: a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc cos A.

name: problems in three dimensions using trigonometry
explanation: Applying trigonometric methods to solve lengths and angles in 3D figures by decomposing into triangles.

name: graphs of sine, cosine and tangent functions
explanation: Plotting periodic trigonometric functions with their characteristic ranges, periods, and asymptotes.

name: amplitude and period changes in trigonometric graphs
explanation: Effects of multiplying function by a constant (amplitude) and changing argument coefficient (period).

name: general solutions of trigonometric equations
explanation: Finding all solutions to equations like sin x = k or cos x = k by adding integer multiples of the period.

name: distance formula between two points
explanation: Calculating the distance between points (x1,y1) and (x2,y2) as sqrt((x2-x1)^2 + (y2-y1)^2).

name: midpoint formula
explanation: Finding the midpoint of segment joining (x1,y1) and (x2,y2) as ((x1+x2)/2, (y1+y2)/2).

name: slope of a line between two points
explanation: Calculating slope m = (y2 - y1)/(x2 - x1) for points (x1,y1) and (x2,y2).

name: conditions for parallel and perpendicular lines
explanation: Lines are parallel if slopes are equal; perpendicular if product of slopes is -1.

name: area of triangle using coordinate geometry
explanation: Area = (1/2) |x1 y2 - x2 y1| for triangle with vertices at (0,0), (x1,y1), (x2,y2).

name: equation of a line in slope-intercept and general form
explanation: Expressing line equations as y = mx + c or ax + by + c = 0, with slope and intercept interpretations.

name: internal division of a line segment in given ratio
explanation: Finding coordinates of point dividing segment between (x1,y1) and (x2,y2) internally in ratio a:b.

name: centroid of a triangle
explanation: Point of concurrency of medians; coordinates are averages of vertices' coordinates.

name: circumcentre of a triangle
explanation: Point of intersection of perpendicular bisectors of sides; center of circumscribed circle.

name: orthocentre of a triangle
explanation: Point of concurrency of altitudes (perpendiculars from vertices to opposite sides).

name: perpendicular distance from point to line
explanation: Distance from (x1,y1) to line ax + by + c = 0 is |a x1 + b y1 + c| / sqrt(a^2 + b^2).

name: angle between two lines from slopes
explanation: Angle θ between lines with slopes m1 and m2 satisfies tan θ = |(m1 - m2) / (1 + m1 m2)|.

name: average rate of change of a function
explanation: Slope of the secant line between two points on a curve, calculated as (f(b) - f(a)) / (b - a).

name: limit of a function at a point
explanation: Value that f(x) approaches as x approaches a given point a, denoted lim_{x→a} f(x).

name: continuity of a function at a point
explanation: A function is continuous at x = a if lim_{x→a} f(x) = f(a), with no breaks or jumps in the graph.

name: differentiation from first principles
explanation: Definition of derivative as the limit of the difference quotient: f'(x) = lim_{h→0} (f(x+h) - f(x))/h.

name: power rule for differentiation
explanation: Derivative of x^n is n x^{n-1} for any real number n.

name: sum and difference rule for differentiation
explanation: Derivative of sum or difference of functions is the sum or difference of their derivatives.

name: product rule for differentiation
explanation: Derivative of product u v is u (dv/dx) + v (du/dx).

name: quotient rule for differentiation
explanation: Derivative of quotient u/v is (v du/dx - u dv/dx)/v^2.

name: chain rule for differentiation
explanation: Derivative of composite function y = f(g(x)) is dy/dx = dy/du * du/dx.

name: second derivative
explanation: Derivative of the first derivative, representing the rate of change of the slope.

name: derivatives of sine, cosine and tangent functions
explanation: d/dx(sin x) = cos x; d/dx(cos x) = -sin x; d/dx(tan x) = sec^2 x.

name: derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions
explanation: Derivatives of arcsin(x/a), arccos(x/a), arctan(x/a) with respect to x using chain rule.

name: derivative of exponential functions
explanation: Derivative of e^{x} is e^{x}; derivative of a^{x} is a^{x} ln a.

name: derivative of logarithmic functions
explanation: Derivative of ln x is 1/x; derivative of ln f(x) is f'(x)/f(x).

name: trigonometric identities: Pythagorean and reciprocal
explanation: Fundamental identities such as sin^2 θ + cos^2 θ = 1, tan θ = sin θ / cos θ, and reciprocal definitions.

name: compound angle formulae for sine, cosine and tangent
explanation: Formulas expressing sin(A±B), cos(A±B), tan(A±B) in terms of sin, cos, tan of A and B.

name: double-angle formulae for sine, cosine and tangent
explanation: Formulas for sin 2A, cos 2A, tan 2A expressed in terms of sin A, cos A, tan A.

name: sum-to-product and product-to-sum trigonometric formulae
explanation: Formulas converting sums or differences of sines and cosines into products, and vice versa.

name: inverse trigonometric functions and their properties
explanation: Definition and evaluation of arcsin, arccos, arctan functions and their use in expressions and equations.

name: equation of a circle with center at origin
explanation: Equation x^2 + y^2 = r^2 represents a circle centered at (0,0) with radius r.

name: equation of a circle with center not at origin
explanation: Equation (x - h)^2 + (y - k)^2 = r^2 represents a circle centered at (h,k) with radius r.

name: general form of circle equation and center-radius extraction
explanation: Circle equation in form x^2 + y^2 + 2gx + 2fy + c = 0 has center (-g,-f) and radius sqrt(g^2 + f^2 - c).

name: tangent to a circle and perpendicularity to radius
explanation: A tangent line to a circle at point P is perpendicular to the radius drawn from the center to P.

name: equations of tangents parallel or perpendicular to given line
explanation: Lines parallel to ax + by + c = 0 have form ax + by + k = 0; perpendicular lines have form bx - ay + k = 0.

name: equations of tangents from external point to circle
explanation: Finding tangent lines from a point outside a circle by solving for slopes that yield perpendicular distance equal to radius.

name: length of tangent from a point to a circle
explanation: Length of tangent PT from point P to circle with center C and radius r is sqrt(|CP|^2 - r^2).

name: finding equation of common chord of two circles
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: finding equation of common chord of two circles

name: perpendicular from the centre of a circle to a chord bisects the chord
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: perpendicular from the centre of a circle to a chord bisects the chord

name: irrational number as non-terminating non-repeating decimal
explanation: An irrational number is a real number that cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers and has a decimal expansion that neither terminates nor repeats.

name: simplification of surds by factorization
explanation: The process of simplifying surds by expressing the radicand as a product of a perfect square and another factor, then separating the square root accordingly.

name: geometric construction of line segment of length sqrt(2)
explanation: Using compass and straightedge to construct a line segment on the number line whose length is the square root of 2, based on right triangle properties.

name: geometric construction of line segment of length sqrt(3)
explanation: Using compass and straightedge to construct a line segment on the number line whose length is the square root of 3, based on right triangle properties.

name: imaginary unit i as sqrt(-1)
explanation: The imaginary unit i is defined as the square root of -1, enabling the extension of the real number system to complex numbers.

name: complex number rectangular form
explanation: Representation of a complex number as the sum of a real part and an imaginary part, expressed as a + bi where a and b are real numbers.

name: addition of complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Adding complex numbers by separately adding their real parts and their imaginary parts.

name: subtraction of complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Subtracting complex numbers by separately subtracting their real parts and their imaginary parts.

name: multiplication of complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Multiplying complex numbers using distributive property and the identity i^2 = -1, then simplifying to rectangular form.

name: powers of imaginary unit i and cyclic pattern
explanation: The powers of i cycle every four steps: i^1 = i, i^2 = -1, i^3 = -i, i^4 = 1, and so on.

name: complex conjugate of a complex number
explanation: Given a complex number a + bi, its complex conjugate is a - bi, which reflects the number across the real axis in the complex plane.

name: division of complex numbers using complex conjugates
explanation: Dividing complex numbers by multiplying numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator to rationalize the denominator.

name: equality of complex numbers by equating real and imaginary parts
explanation: Two complex numbers are equal if and only if their real parts are equal and their imaginary parts are equal.

name: square root of complex number by equating real and imaginary parts
explanation: Expressing the square root of a complex number in the form a + bi by solving simultaneous equations derived from squaring a + bi.

name: triangle inequality for complex numbers
explanation: For complex numbers z1 and z2, the modulus satisfies |z1 + z2| ≤ |z1| + |z2|, with equality under specific conditions.

name: transformation of complex numbers by multiplication by real scalar
explanation: Multiplying a complex number by a real scalar stretches or contracts it radially from the origin, possibly reflecting it if the scalar is negative.

name: translation of complex numbers by addition
explanation: Adding a fixed complex number to others translates all points in the complex plane by the vector represented by the fixed complex number.

name: rotation of complex numbers by multiplication by i
explanation: Multiplying a complex number by i rotates it counterclockwise by 90 degrees about the origin in the complex plane.

name: rotation of complex numbers by multiplication by powers of i
explanation: Multiplying by i^n rotates a complex number by 90n degrees counterclockwise about the origin.

name: conjugate roots theorem for polynomials with real coefficients
explanation: If a polynomial with real coefficients has a complex root z, then its complex conjugate ̅z is also a root.

name: polar form (modulus-argument form) of a complex number
explanation: Expressing a complex number as r(cos θ + i sin θ), where r is the modulus and θ is the argument (angle) of the number.

name: conversion between rectangular and polar forms of complex numbers
explanation: Using trigonometric relations x = r cos θ and y = r sin θ to convert between rectangular (x + iy) and polar forms.

name: principal value of argument of a complex number
explanation: The argument θ of a complex number is taken to be in the interval (-π, π], representing the angle with the positive real axis.

name: multiplication of complex numbers in polar form
explanation: Multiplying complex numbers in polar form multiplies their moduli and adds their arguments.

name: division of complex numbers in polar form
explanation: Dividing complex numbers in polar form divides their moduli and subtracts their arguments.

name: de Moivre's theorem for integer powers
explanation: For integer n, (cos θ + i sin θ)^n = cos nθ + i sin nθ, relating powers of complex numbers in polar form to multiple angles.

name: proof of de Moivre's theorem by induction
explanation: Using mathematical induction to prove that (cos θ + i sin θ)^n = cos nθ + i sin nθ for all positive integers n.

name: application of de Moivre's theorem to find powers of complex numbers
explanation: Using de Moivre's theorem to simplify expressions of complex numbers raised to integer powers in polar form.

name: expressing cosine and sine of multiple angles using de Moivre's theorem
explanation: Deriving formulas for cos nθ and sin nθ in terms of powers of cos θ and sin θ using de Moivre's theorem.

name: finding nth roots of complex numbers using de Moivre's theorem
explanation: Using de Moivre's theorem and polar form to find all nth roots of a complex number by considering arguments with added multiples of 2π.

name: simplifying powers of complex conjugates
explanation: Using properties of complex conjugates and de Moivre's theorem to simplify expressions involving powers of conjugates.

name: transformations of complex numbers by multiplication and addition
explanation: Describing geometric transformations such as stretching, contracting, rotating, reflecting, and translating complex numbers via multiplication and addition.

name: enlargement of geometric figures with scale factor
explanation: A transformation that produces a similar figure by scaling distances from a fixed centre by a scale factor greater than zero.

name: finding centre of enlargement from object and image
explanation: Determining the fixed point (centre) from which a figure is enlarged by extending lines joining corresponding points of object and image.

name: effect of scale factor on area in enlargements
explanation: When a figure is enlarged by scale factor k, its area is multiplied by k squared.

name: construction of angle bisector
explanation: Using compass and straightedge to construct a line that divides an angle into two equal parts.

name: construction of perpendicular bisector of a line segment
explanation: Using compass and straightedge to construct a line perpendicular to a segment at its midpoint.

name: construction of circumcircle of a triangle
explanation: Constructing the circle passing through all three vertices of a triangle by finding the intersection of perpendicular bisectors of sides.

name: construction of incircle of a triangle
explanation: Constructing the circle tangent to all three sides of a triangle by finding the intersection of angle bisectors.

name: construction of centroid of a triangle
explanation: Finding the point of concurrency of the medians of a triangle, where a median connects a vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.

name: construction of orthocentre of a triangle
explanation: Finding the point of concurrency of the altitudes of a triangle, where an altitude is a perpendicular from a vertex to the opposite side.

name: antidifferentiation (indefinite integration) of power functions
explanation: Finding a function whose derivative is the given function, specifically integrating x^n to get x^{n+1}/(n+1) + c for n ≠ -1.

name: constant of integration in indefinite integrals
explanation: An arbitrary constant added to the antiderivative to represent the family of functions differing by a constant.

name: integration of sums and constant multiples
explanation: The integral of a sum is the sum of the integrals; constants can be factored out of the integral.

name: integration of exponential functions
explanation: Integrating exponential functions of the form e^{ax} results in (1/a) e^{ax} + c.

name: integration of trigonometric functions with linear arguments
explanation: Integrals of sin(ax) and cos(ax) are (-1/a) cos(ax) + c and (1/a) sin(ax) + c respectively.

name: applications of integration to kinematics
explanation: Using integration to find velocity and displacement functions from acceleration, and displacement from velocity.

name: definite integral as area under a curve
explanation: The definite integral of a function between two limits gives the net area between the curve and the x-axis over that interval.

name: area between two curves using integration
explanation: The area between two curves is found by integrating the difference of the upper and lower functions over the interval of intersection.

name: average value of a function over an interval
explanation: The average value of a continuous function over [a,b] is (1/(b-a)) times the definite integral of the function over [a,b].

name: rate of change as derivative
explanation: The rate of change of a quantity with respect to another is given by the derivative of one variable with respect to the other.

name: related rates problems using chain rule
explanation: Solving problems involving rates of change of related variables by differentiating implicitly with respect to time.

name: tangent line to a curve at a point
explanation: The line that touches a curve at a point with the same slope as the curve at that point, found using the derivative.

name: increasing and decreasing functions via first derivative test
explanation: A function is increasing where its derivative is positive and decreasing where its derivative is negative.

name: stationary points of a function
explanation: Points where the first derivative is zero, indicating potential maxima, minima, or points of inflection.

name: second derivative test for nature of stationary points
explanation: Using the sign of the second derivative at a stationary point to determine if it is a local maximum (negative) or minimum (positive).

name: point of inflection of a curve
explanation: A point where the curve changes concavity and the second derivative is zero and changes sign.

name: graph of derivative function (slope function)
explanation: The graph of the first derivative of a function, representing the slope of the original function at each point.

name: maximization and minimization problems using calculus
explanation: Finding maximum or minimum values of functions by setting derivatives to zero and applying second derivative test.

name: binomial distribution for discrete random variables
explanation: Probability distribution describing the number of successes in n independent Bernoulli trials with constant success probability p.

name: Bernoulli trial
explanation: A random experiment with exactly two possible outcomes, success or failure, with fixed probabilities.

name: tree diagram for probability
explanation: A graphical representation of all possible outcomes of sequential events with probabilities assigned to branches.

name: independent events and multiplication rule
explanation: Events are independent if the occurrence of one does not affect the probability of the other; their joint probability is the product of their probabilities.

name: expected value of a discrete random variable
explanation: The weighted average of all possible values of a discrete random variable, weighted by their probabilities.

name: fair game and expected value
explanation: A game is fair if the expected net gain (expected value minus cost) is zero; positive expected value favors the player, negative favors the house.

name: probability simulations
explanation: Using physical or computational methods to imitate random experiments for estimating probabilities.

name: function as a relation with unique output for each input
explanation: A function assigns exactly one output value to each input value in its domain.

name: domain, codomain, and range of a function
explanation: Domain is the set of inputs, codomain is the set of possible outputs, and range is the set of actual outputs of a function.

name: vertical line test for functions
explanation: A graphical test to determine if a relation is a function by checking if any vertical line intersects the graph more than once.

name: composition of functions
explanation: Applying one function to the result of another function, denoted as (g ∘ f)(x) = g(f(x)).

name: injective (one-to-one) function
explanation: A function where each output corresponds to exactly one unique input; no two inputs map to the same output.

name: surjective (onto) function
explanation: A function where every element of the codomain is mapped to by at least one element of the domain.

name: bijective function
explanation: A function that is both injective and surjective, establishing a one-to-one correspondence between domain and codomain.

name: inverse function
explanation: A function that reverses the mapping of the original function, swapping inputs and outputs, existing only for bijections.

name: graph transformations: translations
explanation: Shifting the graph of a function vertically by adding/subtracting a constant or horizontally by replacing x with x ± a.

name: graph transformations: reflections
explanation: Reflecting the graph of a function across the x-axis by multiplying by -1 or across the y-axis by replacing x with -x.

name: graph transformations: stretches and compressions
explanation: Multiplying the function by a constant to stretch or compress the graph vertically.

name: exponential function
explanation: A function of the form f(x) = a^x where a > 0 and a ≠ 1, characterized by rapid growth or decay.

name: logarithmic function as inverse of exponential
explanation: The logarithmic function is the inverse of the exponential function, defined as y = log_a x where a > 0, a ≠ 1.

name: normal distribution
explanation: A continuous probability distribution characterized by a symmetric bell-shaped curve defined by mean μ and standard deviation σ.

name: empirical rule for normal distribution
explanation: Approximately 68%, 95%, and 99.7% of data lie within 1, 2, and 3 standard deviations from the mean in a normal distribution.

name: standard score (z-score)
explanation: The number of standard deviations a data point is from the mean, calculated as z = (x - μ)/σ.

name: correlation coefficient (Pearson's r)
explanation: A measure of linear correlation between two variables, ranging from -1 (perfect negative) to 1 (perfect positive).

name: line of best fit (least squares regression line)
explanation: A straight line that best represents the data on a scatter plot, minimizing the sum of squared vertical distances from the points to the line.

name: sampling distribution of the mean
explanation: The probability distribution of sample means from all possible samples of a fixed size from a population.

name: central limit theorem
explanation: For sufficiently large sample size, the sampling distribution of the mean approximates a normal distribution regardless of the population's distribution.

name: standard error of the mean
explanation: The standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the mean, calculated as σ/√n.

name: confidence interval for population proportion using margin of error approximation
explanation: An interval estimate for a population proportion p given by sample proportion ± 1/√n at 95% confidence level.

name: confidence interval for population proportion using standard error
explanation: An interval estimate for a population proportion p given by sample proportion ± 1.96 × sqrt(p(1-p)/n) at 95% confidence level.

name: hypothesis testing for population proportion
explanation: Testing a claim about a population proportion by comparing the sample proportion's confidence interval or test statistic to the hypothesized value.

name: confidence interval for population mean with known standard deviation
explanation: An interval estimate for population mean μ given by sample mean ± 1.96 × (σ/√n) at 95% confidence level.

name: hypothesis testing for population mean
explanation: Testing a claim about a population mean by calculating a test statistic z and comparing it to critical values or p-values at a chosen significance level.

name: p-value in hypothesis testing
explanation: The probability of observing a test statistic as extreme as, or more extreme than, the observed value under the null hypothesis.

name: scatter diagram
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: scatter diagram

name: function as unique output assignment
explanation: Understanding that a function assigns exactly one output value for each input value.

name: graphing linear functions with rational coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form ax + b where a and b are rational numbers and x is a real number.

name: forming composite functions
explanation: Creating a new function by applying one function to the result of another function.

name: graphing quadratic functions with integer coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form ax^2 + bx + c where a, b, and c are integers and x is a real number.

name: graphing cubic functions with integer coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d where a, b, c, and d are integers and x is a real number.

name: graphing exponential functions with natural base coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form ab^x where a is a natural number and b and x are real numbers.

name: interpreting equations f(x) = g(x) as function comparisons
explanation: Understanding that equations equating two functions represent points where their outputs are equal.

name: graphical approximation of solutions to f(x) = 0
explanation: Using graphs to estimate the input values where a function equals zero (roots).

name: graphical approximation of solutions to f(x) = k
explanation: Using graphs to estimate input values where a function equals a constant k.

name: graphical approximation of solutions to f(x) = g(x)
explanation: Using graphs to estimate input values where two functions have equal outputs.

name: investigating the concept of function limits
explanation: Exploring the behavior of function values as inputs approach a particular point.

name: recognising surjective functions
explanation: Identifying functions where every possible output value has at least one corresponding input value.

name: recognising injective functions
explanation: Identifying functions where each output value corresponds to at most one input value.

name: recognising bijective functions
explanation: Identifying functions that are both injective and surjective, establishing a one-to-one correspondence between inputs and outputs.

name: finding inverse of bijective functions
explanation: Determining the function that reverses the effect of a bijective function, swapping inputs and outputs.

name: sketching inverse function graphs from original function graphs
explanation: Drawing the graph of an inverse function by reflecting the original function's graph across the line y = x.

name: expressing quadratic functions in complete square form
explanation: Rewriting quadratic functions as a perfect square trinomial plus or minus a constant to facilitate analysis.

name: using complete square form to find roots and turning points
explanation: Applying the complete square form of a quadratic to identify its zeros and vertex coordinates.

name: graphing quadratic functions with rational coefficients
explanation: Plotting quadratic functions where coefficients a, b, and c are rational numbers and x is real.

name: graphing exponential functions with real coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form ab^x where a and b are real numbers and x is real.

name: graphing logarithmic functions
explanation: Plotting functions that are the inverse of exponential functions, typically log base a of x.

name: graphing trigonometric functions
explanation: Plotting functions such as sine, cosine, and tangent over real inputs.

name: informal exploration of limits and continuity
explanation: Investigating the behavior of functions near points to understand limits and whether functions are continuous.

name: finding first and second derivatives of linear functions by rule
explanation: Calculating the first and second derivatives of linear functions using differentiation rules.

name: finding first and second derivatives of quadratic functions by rule
explanation: Calculating the first and second derivatives of quadratic functions using differentiation rules.

name: finding first and second derivatives of cubic functions by rule
explanation: Calculating the first and second derivatives of cubic functions using differentiation rules.

name: associating derivatives with slopes and tangent lines
explanation: Understanding that the derivative at a point gives the slope of the tangent line to the function's graph at that point.

name: applying differentiation to rates of change
explanation: Using derivatives to calculate how quantities change with respect to one another.

name: applying differentiation to maxima and minima
explanation: Using derivatives to find local maximum and minimum values of functions.

name: applying differentiation to curve sketching
explanation: Using derivatives to analyze function behavior and draw accurate graphs.

name: differentiating linear functions from first principles
explanation: Calculating derivatives of linear functions using the limit definition of the derivative.

name: differentiating quadratic functions from first principles
explanation: Calculating derivatives of quadratic functions using the limit definition of the derivative.

name: differentiating polynomial functions
explanation: Applying differentiation rules to functions expressed as sums of powers of x with coefficients.

name: differentiating exponential functions
explanation: Finding derivatives of functions where the variable is in the exponent.

name: differentiating trigonometric functions
explanation: Calculating derivatives of sine, cosine, and other trigonometric functions.

name: differentiating functions with rational powers
explanation: Finding derivatives of functions where variables are raised to fractional exponents.

name: differentiating inverse functions
explanation: Calculating derivatives of functions that are inverses of other functions.

name: differentiating logarithmic functions
explanation: Finding derivatives of logarithmic functions such as natural logs.

name: differentiating sums and differences of functions
explanation: Applying linearity of differentiation to sums and differences of functions.

name: differentiating products of functions
explanation: Using the product rule to find derivatives of products of two functions.

name: differentiating quotients of functions
explanation: Using the quotient rule to find derivatives of ratios of two functions.

name: differentiating compositions of functions
explanation: Applying the chain rule to find derivatives of composed functions.

name: using differentiation to find slope of tangent to a circle
explanation: Applying derivative concepts to determine the slope of a tangent line to a circle at a given point.

name: recognising integration as reverse of differentiation
explanation: Understanding that integration undoes the process of differentiation.

name: using integration to find average value of a function over an interval
explanation: Calculating the mean value of a function on a given interval using definite integrals.

name: integrating sums and differences of functions
explanation: Applying linearity of integration to sums and differences of functions.

name: integrating constant multiples of functions
explanation: Using the property that constants can be factored out of integrals.

name: integrating power functions xa where a ∈ Q
explanation: Finding integrals of functions where the variable is raised to a rational power.

name: integrating exponential functions of the form ax where a ∈ R, a > 0
explanation: Calculating integrals of exponential functions with positive real bases.

name: integrating sine functions of the form sin(ax) where a ∈ R
explanation: Finding integrals of sine functions with real coefficients inside the argument.

name: integrating cosine functions of the form cos(ax) where a ∈ R
explanation: Finding integrals of cosine functions with real coefficients inside the argument.

name: determining areas of plane regions bounded by polynomial curves
explanation: Using integration to calculate the area enclosed between polynomial function graphs and the x-axis or other curves.

name: determining areas of plane regions bounded by exponential curves
explanation: Using integration to calculate the area enclosed between exponential function graphs and the x-axis or other curves.

name: Generating arithmetic expressions from repeating patterns
explanation: Creating arithmetic expressions that represent the nth term in a sequence based on identified repeating patterns.

name: Using tables to represent repeating-pattern situations
explanation: Organizing inputs and outputs of a repeating pattern in tabular form to analyze relationships.

name: Generalising and explaining numeric and verbal patterns
explanation: Describing and extending patterns using both words and numbers to identify underlying rules.

name: Representing linear patterns with tables, diagrams, and graphs
explanation: Using multiple representations such as tables, diagrams, and graphs to model and analyze linear relationships.

name: Developing and using generalising strategies for patterns
explanation: Formulating and applying methods to extend and predict patterns based on observed data.

name: Finding formulae for linear relationships from patterns
explanation: Deriving algebraic expressions that represent linear relationships identified in data or patterns.

name: Identifying features of linear relationships across representations
explanation: Recognizing characteristics such as slope and intercept in tables, graphs, physical models, and verbal or algebraic formulae.

name: Understanding constant rate of change in linear relationships
explanation: Recognizing that linear relationships have a constant difference in output values per unit change in input.

name: Recognizing and solving problems involving direct proportion
explanation: Identifying relationships where one quantity is a constant multiple of another and solving related problems.

name: Using graphs to represent quantitative phenomena
explanation: Interpreting and analyzing graphs that depict changes in quantities over time or other variables.

name: Describing quantity and change of quantity on graphs
explanation: Explaining how the values and rates of change are represented by the shape and slope of a graph.

name: Evaluating algebraic expressions given variable values
explanation: Substituting numerical values into algebraic expressions and calculating the resulting value.

name: Expanding and regrouping algebraic expressions
explanation: Applying distributive property to remove brackets and combining like terms to simplify expressions.

name: Factorising quadratic expressions of order 2
explanation: Rewriting second-degree polynomial expressions as products of linear factors.

name: Adding and subtracting linear and quadratic expressions with integer coefficients
explanation: Performing addition and subtraction on expressions of the form (ax+by+c) and (ax²+bx+c) where coefficients are integers.

name: Using associative and distributive properties to simplify expressions
explanation: Applying associative and distributive laws to simplify complex algebraic expressions involving multiple terms and brackets.

name: Multiplying binomials
explanation: Expanding the product of two binomial expressions such as (x±y)(w±z).

name: Rearranging formulae
explanation: Manipulating algebraic equations to isolate a specific variable on one side of the equation.

name: Performing arithmetic operations on polynomials and rational algebraic expressions
explanation: Adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing polynomial and rational expressions, including careful use of brackets and surds.

name: Applying the binomial theorem
explanation: Using the binomial theorem to expand powers of binomial expressions.

name: Solving linear equations of the form f(x) = g(x) with rational coefficients
explanation: Finding solutions to equations where both sides are linear expressions with rational coefficients.

name: Using graphic, numeric, and mental strategies to solve linear equations
explanation: Employing visual graphs, numerical tables, and mental calculations to find solutions to linear equations.

name: Solving simultaneous linear equations with two unknowns
explanation: Finding values of two variables that satisfy two linear equations simultaneously.

name: Solving simultaneous equations with one linear and one quadratic equation
explanation: Finding solutions to systems consisting of one linear and one quadratic equation with two unknowns, with restrictions on coefficients.

name: Forming quadratic equations given whole number roots
explanation: Constructing quadratic equations when the roots are known whole numbers.

name: Using the Factor Theorem for polynomials
explanation: Applying the Factor Theorem to determine factors and roots of polynomial expressions.

name: Solving cubic equations with at least one integer root
explanation: Finding solutions to third-degree polynomial equations that have at least one integer root.

name: Solving simultaneous linear equations with three unknowns
explanation: Finding values of three variables that satisfy three linear equations simultaneously.

name: Solving linear inequalities of the form g(x) ≤ k or g(x) ≥ k with rational coefficients
explanation: Finding solution sets for inequalities where g(x) is a linear expression with rational coefficients.

name: Solving strict linear inequalities of the form g(x) < k or g(x) > k with rational coefficients
explanation: Determining solution sets for strict inequalities involving linear expressions with rational coefficients.

name: Using absolute value notation and solving absolute value inequalities
explanation: Applying the notation |x| and solving inequalities involving absolute values such as |x - a| < b or |x - a| > b.

name: Solving quadratic inequalities of the form g(x) ≤ k or g(x) ≥ k
explanation: Finding solution sets for inequalities where g(x) is a quadratic expression with rational coefficients.

name: Using the Conjugate Root Theorem to find polynomial roots
explanation: Applying the theorem that complex roots of polynomials with real coefficients occur in conjugate pairs to find roots.

name: Working with complex numbers in rectangular and polar form
explanation: Representing complex numbers as a + bi (rectangular) or r(Cos θ + i Sin θ) (polar) and using these forms to solve equations.

name: Using De Moivre’s Theorem for powers of complex numbers
explanation: Applying De Moivre’s Theorem to raise complex numbers in polar form to integer powers.

name: Proving De Moivre’s Theorem by induction
explanation: Using mathematical induction to prove De Moivre’s Theorem for natural number exponents.

name: Applying nth roots of unity and trigonometric identities
explanation: Using the concept of nth roots of unity and identities like Cos 3θ = 4 Cos³ θ – 3 Cos θ in complex number contexts.
broader_concept: Roots of unity and trigonometric identities

name: line passing through a given point
explanation: A line that contains a specific point, defined by set membership within a plane.

name: undeﬁned geometric terms
explanation: Basic geometric terms such as angle, degree, length, line, plane, point, ray, real number, and set that are accepted without formal definition.

name: defined geometric terms
explanation: Geometric terms with explicit definitions, including area, parallel lines, parallelogram, right angle, triangle, congruent triangles, similar triangles, tangent to a circle, and area.

name: acute angle
explanation: An angle measuring less than 90 degrees.

name: alternate angles
explanation: Pairs of angles formed when a transversal crosses two lines, lying on opposite sides of the transversal and inside the two lines.

name: angle bisector
explanation: A ray that divides an angle into two equal angles.

name: arc of a circle
explanation: A continuous portion of the circumference of a circle defined by two endpoints.

name: area of a disc
explanation: The measure of the space enclosed by a circle, equal to π times the square of the radius.

name: base, apex, and height of triangle or parallelogram
explanation: The base is a chosen side, the apex is the vertex opposite the base, and the height is the perpendicular distance from the apex to the base.

name: chord of a circle
explanation: A line segment with both endpoints on the circle.

name: circumcircle of a triangle
explanation: The unique circle passing through all three vertices of a triangle.

name: circumference of a circle
explanation: The total length around a circle, equal to 2π times the radius.

name: circumradius
explanation: The radius of the circumcircle of a triangle.

name: collinear points
explanation: Three or more points that lie on the same straight line.

name: concurrent lines
explanation: Three or more lines that intersect at a single point.

name: convex quadrilateral
explanation: A four-sided polygon where all interior angles are less than 180 degrees and the polygon contains all line segments between any two points within it.

name: corresponding angles
explanation: Pairs of angles in matching corners when a transversal crosses two lines.

name: diameter of a circle
explanation: A chord passing through the center of the circle; its length is twice the radius.

name: disc
explanation: The region of the plane bounded by a circle, including its interior.

name: distance between points
explanation: The length of the line segment connecting two points, denoted |AB|.

name: equilateral triangle
explanation: A triangle with all three sides equal in length.

name: exterior angles of a triangle
explanation: Angles formed outside a triangle when one side is extended; each exterior angle equals the sum of the two interior opposite angles.

name: full angle
explanation: An angle whose arms coincide and whose interior is the entire plane, measuring 360 degrees.

name: hypotenuse
explanation: The side opposite the right angle in a right-angled triangle; the longest side.

name: incentre of a triangle
explanation: The point where the angle bisectors of a triangle intersect; center of the incircle.

name: incircle of a triangle
explanation: The circle inside a triangle tangent to all three sides.

name: inradius
explanation: The radius of the incircle of a triangle.

name: interior opposite angles
explanation: Pairs of interior angles on opposite sides of a transversal intersecting two lines.

name: isosceles triangle
explanation: A triangle with exactly two sides equal in length.

name: median of a triangle
explanation: A line segment joining a vertex of a triangle to the midpoint of the opposite side.

name: midpoint of a segment
explanation: The point on a line segment that divides it into two equal parts.

name: null angle
explanation: An angle whose arms coincide and whose interior is empty, measuring 0 degrees.

name: obtuse angle
explanation: An angle measuring more than 90 degrees but less than 180 degrees.

name: perpendicular bisector of a segment
explanation: A line perpendicular to a segment that passes through its midpoint.

name: perpendicular lines
explanation: Two lines intersecting at a right angle (90 degrees).

name: point of contact of a tangent
explanation: The unique point where a tangent line touches a circle.

name: polygon
explanation: A closed plane figure formed by a finite chain of straight line segments connected end-to-end without crossings.

name: quadrilateral
explanation: A polygon with four sides and four vertices.

name: radius of a circle
explanation: A line segment from the center of a circle to any point on the circle.

name: ratio of segment division
explanation: The comparison of lengths when a point divides a segment into two parts, expressed as s:t where |AC|/|CB| = s/t.

name: rectangle
explanation: A quadrilateral with four right angles.

name: reflex angle
explanation: An angle measuring more than 180 degrees but less than 360 degrees.

name: regular polygon
explanation: A polygon with all sides and all angles equal.

name: rhombus
explanation: A quadrilateral with all four sides equal in length.

name: right angle
explanation: An angle measuring exactly 90 degrees.

name: right-angled triangle
explanation: A triangle with one angle measuring exactly 90 degrees.

name: scalene triangle
explanation: A triangle with no two sides equal in length.

name: sector of a circle
explanation: The region of a circle enclosed by two radii and the arc between them.

name: segment of a circle
explanation: The region of a circle enclosed by a chord and the arc it subtends.

name: set
explanation: A collection of distinct objects, considered as an object in its own right.

name: single ray notation
explanation: A ray starting at a point A and passing through point B, denoted [AB.

name: straight angle
explanation: An angle whose arms are opposite rays forming a straight line, measuring 180 degrees.

name: subset
explanation: A set whose elements are all contained within another set.

name: supplementary angles
explanation: Two angles whose measures add up to 180 degrees.

name: transversal line
explanation: A line that intersects two or more other lines at distinct points.

name: vertically-opposite angles
explanation: Pairs of angles opposite each other when two lines intersect; these angles are equal.

name: two points axiom
explanation: The axiom stating that exactly one line passes through any two distinct points.

name: line segment
explanation: The part of a line between two points, including the endpoints.

name: ray
explanation: A part of a line that starts at a point and extends infinitely in one direction.

name: ruler axiom
explanation: Axiom defining properties of distance between points, including non-negativity, symmetry, additivity, and the existence of points at given distances on rays.

name: midpoint of a segment definition
explanation: The point on a segment dividing it into two equal lengths.

name: convex set
explanation: A set in the plane containing the entire segment connecting any two of its points.

name: angle vertex and arms
explanation: An angle consists of a vertex point and two rays (arms) starting at the vertex.

name: angle classification by convexity and arm position
explanation: Classification of angles into null, ordinary, straight, reflex, and full based on arm coincidence and convexity of interior.

name: angle notation
explanation: Notation for angles using three points with vertex in the middle, e.g., \BAC, or Greek letters for unnamed angles.

name: degree measure of an angle
explanation: The measure of an angle in degrees, ranging from 0° to 360°, with ordinary angles less than 180°.

name: protractor axiom
explanation: Axiom stating properties of degree measures of angles, including existence and uniqueness of rays forming given angles and additivity of angles.

name: angle bisector ray
explanation: A ray dividing an angle into two equal angles, each half the measure of the original angle.

name: right angle definition
explanation: An angle measuring exactly 90 degrees.

name: acute and obtuse angle definitions
explanation: Acute angles measure less than 90 degrees; obtuse angles measure more than 90 degrees.

name: supplementary angles definition
explanation: Two angles whose measures add to 180 degrees.

name: perpendicular lines definition
explanation: Two lines intersecting to form a right angle.

name: vertically opposite angles theorem
explanation: The theorem stating that vertically opposite angles formed by two intersecting lines are equal.

name: triangle congruence definition
explanation: Two triangles are congruent if all corresponding sides and angles are equal.

name: triangle angle notation
explanation: Using vertex names to denote angles in a triangle, e.g., \A for angle at vertex A.

name: triangle congruence criteria SAS, ASA, SSS
explanation: Criteria for triangle congruence: Side-Angle-Side, Angle-Side-Angle, and Side-Side-Side.

name: right-angled triangle definition
explanation: A triangle with one right angle; the side opposite the right angle is the hypotenuse.

name: isosceles triangle properties
explanation: In an isosceles triangle, the angles opposite the equal sides are equal, and vice versa.

name: parallel lines definition
explanation: Two lines that are either identical or have no points in common.

name: axiom of parallels
explanation: Given a line and a point not on it, there is exactly one line through the point parallel to the given line.

name: transversal of two lines
explanation: A line that intersects two other lines at distinct points.

name: alternate angles theorem
explanation: If a transversal makes equal alternate angles on two lines, then the lines are parallel, and vice versa.

name: angle sum of triangle theorem
explanation: The sum of the interior angles of any triangle is 180 degrees.

name: corresponding angles theorem
explanation: Two lines are parallel if and only if corresponding angles formed by a transversal are equal.

name: exterior angle theorem
explanation: Each exterior angle of a triangle equals the sum of the two interior opposite angles.

name: triangle side-angle inequality theorem
