explanation: The angle opposite the greater side of a triangle is greater, and vice versa.

name: triangle inequality theorem
explanation: The sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle is greater than the length of the third side.

name: perpendicular lines parallelism proposition
explanation: Two lines perpendicular to the same line are parallel to each other.

name: unique perpendicular line through a point proposition
explanation: There is a unique line perpendicular to a given line passing through a given point on or off the line.

name: polygon definition
explanation: A closed chain of line segments laid end-to-end without crossings, forming a plane figure.

name: adjacent and opposite sides and angles of quadrilaterals
explanation: Adjacent sides or angles share a vertex; opposite sides or angles do not share a vertex.

name: rectangle definition
explanation: A quadrilateral with four right angles.

name: rhombus definition
explanation: A quadrilateral with all four sides equal in length.

name: square definition
explanation: A quadrilateral that is both a rectangle and a rhombus, having four equal sides and four right angles.

name: parallelogram definition
explanation: A quadrilateral with both pairs of opposite sides parallel.

name: properties of parallelograms theorem
explanation: In a parallelogram, opposite sides and opposite angles are equal.

name: diagonals bisecting in parallelograms theorem
explanation: The diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other.

name: similar triangles definition
explanation: Triangles with equal corresponding angles and proportional corresponding sides.

name: equal segments cut by parallel lines theorem
explanation: Three parallel lines cutting equal segments on one transversal cut equal segments on any other transversal.

name: segment division in ratio
explanation: A point dividing a segment into parts with lengths in a specified ratio s:t.

name: parallel line cutting sides in equal ratio theorem
explanation: A line parallel to one side of a triangle cuts the other two sides in the same ratio.

name: similarity criterion SAS for triangles
explanation: Two triangles are similar if two sides are in proportion and the included angle is equal.

name: converse of parallel line cutting sides in equal ratio
explanation: If a line cuts two sides of a triangle in the same ratio, then it is parallel to the third side.

name: proportional sides in similar triangles theorem
explanation: In similar triangles, corresponding sides are proportional.

name: converse of proportional sides in similar triangles
explanation: If corresponding sides of two triangles are proportional, then the triangles are similar.

name: Pythagorean theorem
explanation: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

name: converse of Pythagorean theorem
explanation: If the square of one side of a triangle equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides, then the angle opposite that side is a right angle.

name: RHS triangle congruence criterion
explanation: Two right-angled triangles are congruent if their hypotenuse and one other side are equal.

name: perpendicular bisector equidistance proposition
explanation: Any point on the perpendicular bisector of a segment is equidistant from the segment's endpoints.

name: perpendiculars from angle bisector proposition
explanation: Perpendiculars from a point on an angle bisector to the arms of the angle have equal length.

name: altitude of a triangle
explanation: A perpendicular segment from a vertex to the opposite side or its extension, representing the height.

name: area of a triangle
explanation: Half the product of the base length and the corresponding height.

name: area addition property for triangles
explanation: The area of a triangle divided by a segment is the sum of the areas of the two smaller triangles formed.

name: area of rectangle
explanation: The product of the lengths of its two adjacent sides.

name: diagonal bisects area of parallelogram theorem
explanation: A diagonal divides a parallelogram into two congruent triangles of equal area.

name: height of parallelogram
explanation: The perpendicular distance from a base to the opposite side, equal to the height of the corresponding triangle.

name: area of parallelogram
explanation: The product of the base length and the corresponding height.

name: circle definition
explanation: The set of points in a plane at a fixed distance (radius) from a fixed point (center).

name: semicircle
explanation: An arc of a circle whose endpoints are the endpoints of a diameter.

name: angle at a point standing on an arc
explanation: An angle formed at a point outside the arc, subtended by the endpoints of the arc.

name: angle at center theorem
explanation: The angle at the center of a circle standing on an arc is twice any angle at the circumference standing on the same arc.

name: equal angles standing on same arc corollary
explanation: All angles at points of a circle standing on the same arc are equal.

name: angle in a semicircle corollary
explanation: An angle standing on a diameter of a circle is a right angle.

name: right angle standing on chord implies diameter corollary
explanation: If an angle standing on a chord is a right angle, then the chord is a diameter.

name: cyclic quadrilateral definition
explanation: A quadrilateral whose vertices all lie on a single circle.

name: opposite angles of cyclic quadrilateral sum to 180 degrees
explanation: In a cyclic quadrilateral, the sum of each pair of opposite angles is 180 degrees.

name: circle intersection points classification
explanation: Two circles intersect in zero, one, or two points depending on the distance between centers and radii.

name: tangent to a circle definition
explanation: A line that intersects a circle at exactly one point.

name: tangent perpendicular to radius theorem
explanation: A tangent to a circle is perpendicular to the radius drawn to the point of contact.

name: unique tangent line through a point perpendicular to radius
explanation: If a line through a point on a circle is perpendicular to the radius at that point, it is the tangent line.

name: common tangent and centers collinearity corollary
explanation: If two circles share a common tangent at one point, their centers and the point of contact are collinear.

name: perpendicular from center to chord bisects chord theorem
explanation: The perpendicular from the center of a circle to a chord bisects the chord.

name: perpendicular bisector of chord passes through center theorem
explanation: The perpendicular bisector of any chord passes through the center of the circle.

name: geometric constructions with compass and straightedge
explanation: Procedures to construct geometric objects such as angle bisectors, perpendicular bisectors, parallel lines, and triangles using only compass and straightedge.

name: division of segment into equal parts without measurement
explanation: Constructing points dividing a segment into equal segments using geometric methods without measuring lengths.

name: constructing triangle given three sides
explanation: Constructing a triangle when the lengths of all three sides are known.

name: constructing triangle given SAS data
explanation: Constructing a triangle given two sides and the included angle.

name: constructing triangle given ASA data
explanation: Constructing a triangle given two angles and the included side.

name: constructing right-angled triangle given hypotenuse and one side
explanation: Constructing a right-angled triangle when the hypotenuse and one other side length are known.

name: constructing right-angled triangle given one side and one acute angle
explanation: Constructing a right-angled triangle when one side length and one acute angle are known.

name: constructing rectangle given side lengths
explanation: Constructing a rectangle when the lengths of two adjacent sides are known.

name: constructing circumcentre and circumcircle
explanation: Constructing the circumcentre and circumcircle of a triangle using compass and straightedge.

name: constructing incentre and incircle
explanation: Constructing the incentre and incircle of a triangle using compass and straightedge.

name: constructing angle of 60 degrees without protractor
explanation: Constructing a 60-degree angle using compass and straightedge or set squares without measuring tools.

name: constructing tangent to a circle at a given point
explanation: Constructing a line tangent to a circle at a specified point on the circle using compass and straightedge.

name: constructing parallelogram given sides and angles
explanation: Constructing a parallelogram when side lengths and angle measures are known.

name: constructing centroid of a triangle
explanation: Constructing the point where the medians of a triangle intersect using compass and straightedge.

name: constructing orthocentre of a triangle
explanation: Constructing the point where the altitudes of a triangle intersect using compass and straightedge.

name: Systematic listing of experimental outcomes
explanation: The process of enumerating all possible outcomes of an experiment in an organized and complete manner.

name: Fundamental principle of counting
explanation: A counting rule stating that if one event can occur in m ways and another independent event can occur in n ways, then the total number of ways both events can occur is m × n.

name: Informal probability estimation
explanation: Using everyday language and intuition to judge how likely an event is to occur without formal calculation.

name: Probability as a measure on the scale 0 to 1
explanation: Understanding probability as a numerical value between 0 and 1 that quantifies the likelihood of an event occurring.

name: Probability language for equally likely outcomes
explanation: Using terms such as likely, unlikely, certain, impossible, and equally likely to describe events with uniform outcome probabilities.

name: Experimental probability estimation
explanation: Estimating the probability of an event by conducting experiments and calculating the relative frequency of the event's occurrence.

name: Long-run relative frequency interpretation of probability
explanation: Interpreting probability as the proportion of times an event occurs in a large number of repeated trials.

name: Constructing sample spaces for two independent events
explanation: Creating a complete set of all possible ordered pairs of outcomes from two independent experiments.

name: Probability calculation for equally likely outcomes
explanation: Calculating probability by dividing the number of favorable outcomes by the total number of equally likely outcomes.

name: Counting permutations of n distinct objects (n!)
explanation: Calculating the number of ways to arrange n distinct objects in order, given by n factorial.

name: Counting permutations of r objects from n distinct objects
explanation: Calculating the number of ordered arrangements of r objects selected from n distinct objects.

name: Counting combinations of r objects from n distinct objects
explanation: Calculating the number of ways to select r objects from n distinct objects without regard to order.

name: Computing binomial coefficients
explanation: Calculating coefficients representing the number of combinations of r objects from n, often denoted as n choose r.

name: Set theory for probability
explanation: Using sets to represent experiments, outcomes, and sample spaces, facilitating the understanding of events and their relationships.

name: Use of Venn diagrams in probability
explanation: Visual representation of sets and their intersections or unions to illustrate basic probability rules such as AND, OR, and mutually exclusive events.

name: Expected value calculation
explanation: Computing the weighted average of all possible outcomes of a random variable, representing the long-run average result.

name: Role of expected value in decision making
explanation: Using expected value to evaluate fairness and make informed decisions, such as assessing fair games.

name: Addition Rule for probability
explanation: Calculating the probability of the union of two events using P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A ∩ B).

name: Multiplication Rule for independent events
explanation: Calculating the probability of the intersection of two independent events using P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B).

name: Multiplication Rule for dependent events
explanation: Calculating the probability of the intersection of two events where one depends on the other using P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B | A).

name: Sampling with replacement probability
explanation: Calculating probabilities when samples are drawn with replacement, meaning each selection is independent and the population remains unchanged.

name: Sampling without replacement probability
explanation: Calculating probabilities when samples are drawn without replacement, meaning selections affect subsequent probabilities.

name: Conditional probability and its asymmetry
explanation: Understanding that P(A | B) generally does not equal P(B | A) and exploring the implications of this in probability problems.

name: Probability of two independent events both occurring
explanation: Calculating the joint probability of two independent events happening together by multiplying their individual probabilities.

name: Bernoulli trials
explanation: A sequence of independent experiments each with two possible outcomes (success or failure) and constant probability of success.

name: Probability of k successes in n Bernoulli trials
explanation: Calculating the probability of obtaining exactly k successes in n independent Bernoulli trials using the binomial distribution formula.

name: Probability that the kth success occurs on the nth Bernoulli trial
explanation: Calculating the probability that the kth success happens exactly at the nth trial in a sequence of Bernoulli trials.

name: Using simulations to explore sampling variability
explanation: Employing computer-generated random samples to study how sample statistics vary and to construct sampling distributions.

name: Constructing sampling distributions of the mean
explanation: Creating the probability distribution of sample means from repeated samples to understand variability and inference.

name: Reading probabilities from normal distribution tables
explanation: Using standard normal tables to find probabilities associated with normal distribution values.

name: Distinguishing categorical data types: nominal and ordinal
explanation: Classifying categorical data as nominal (no order) or ordinal (with a meaningful order).

name: Distinguishing numerical data types: discrete and continuous
explanation: Classifying numerical data as discrete (countable values) or continuous (measurable values within intervals).

name: Population and sample concepts
explanation: Understanding the difference between the entire group under study (population) and a subset selected for analysis (sample).

name: Generalisation from sample to population
explanation: Evaluating the extent to which conclusions drawn from a sample can be applied to the whole population.

name: Simple random sampling
explanation: Selecting a sample from a population such that every member has an equal chance of being chosen.

name: Stratified sampling
explanation: Dividing the population into subgroups (strata) and randomly sampling from each to ensure representation.

name: Cluster sampling
explanation: Dividing the population into clusters and randomly selecting entire clusters as samples.

name: Quota sampling
explanation: Selecting samples to meet predefined quotas for certain characteristics, without random selection.

name: Recognising sample bias
explanation: Identifying when a sample does not accurately represent the population, leading to biased results.

name: Designing data collection plans
explanation: Planning how to gather data effectively, considering sampling methods, representativeness, and data sources.

name: Use of pie charts for data representation
explanation: Displaying categorical data as sectors of a circle proportional to their frequencies or percentages.

name: Use of bar charts for data representation
explanation: Representing categorical or discrete numerical data with rectangular bars proportional to frequencies or counts.

name: Use of line plots for data representation
explanation: Displaying data points along a number line to show frequency of values, especially for small data sets.

name: Use of histograms with equal intervals
explanation: Representing continuous numerical data by grouping values into equal-sized intervals and displaying frequencies with bars.

name: Use of stem-and-leaf plots
explanation: Organizing numerical data to show distribution while preserving individual data points by splitting digits into stems and leaves.

name: Comparing data sets using graphical displays
explanation: Using appropriate graphs to visually compare characteristics such as center and spread between two or more data sets.

name: Measures of central tendency: mean
explanation: Calculating the average value by summing all data points and dividing by the number of points.

name: Measures of central tendency: median
explanation: Identifying the middle value in an ordered data set, dividing the data into two equal halves.

name: Measures of central tendency: mode
explanation: Determining the most frequently occurring value(s) in a data set.

name: Measure of variability: range
explanation: Calculating the difference between the maximum and minimum values in a data set.

name: Describing bivariate data with scatterplots
explanation: Plotting paired data points on a coordinate plane to visualize relationships between two variables.

name: Correlation coefficient and linear relationship
explanation: Quantifying the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables with a value between -1 and +1.

name: Interpreting correlation coefficient values
explanation: Matching correlation coefficient magnitudes and signs to the appropriate scatterplot patterns to understand relationships.

name: Understanding correlation does not imply causality
explanation: Recognizing that a statistical association between variables does not necessarily mean one causes the other.

name: Measure of variability: standard deviation
explanation: Calculating the average distance of data points from the mean, indicating spread of the data.

name: Measure of variability: interquartile range (IQR)
explanation: Calculating the difference between the third and first quartiles to measure the spread of the middle 50% of data.

name: Finding quartiles
explanation: Determining values that divide ordered data into four equal parts.

name: Recognising outliers in data
explanation: Identifying data points that lie far outside the typical range of the data set.

name: Back-to-back stem-and-leaf plots
explanation: Using two stem-and-leaf plots sharing the same stems to compare two related data sets side by side.

name: Exploring data distribution: symmetry and skewness
explanation: Describing the shape of data distribution by assessing whether it is symmetric or skewed left or right.

name: Drawing line of best fit by eye
explanation: Manually estimating a straight line that best represents the trend in a scatterplot.

name: Making predictions from line of best fit
explanation: Using the line of best fit to estimate values of one variable based on known values of another.

name: Calculating correlation coefficient using a calculator
explanation: Using technology to compute the numerical value of the correlation coefficient from paired data.

name: Using percentiles to assign relative standing
explanation: Determining the position of a data point relative to the rest of the data by calculating the percentile rank.

name: Interpreting graphical summaries of data
explanation: Analyzing graphs such as histograms, bar charts, and scatterplots to understand data characteristics and trends.

name: Relating data interpretation to original question
explanation: Connecting conclusions drawn from data analysis back to the initial problem or research question.

name: Understanding sampling variability
explanation: Recognizing that different samples from the same population can produce varying statistics due to chance.

name: Using variability measures to draw inferences about populations
explanation: Employing statistics like standard deviation and interquartile range to make conclusions about the population from sample data.
